title: Hypothermia Treatment
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: Symptoms of hypothermia in adults and children include:
bullets: Confusion, memory loss , or slurred speech
Drop in body temperature below 95 F
Exhaustion or drowsiness
Loss of consciousness
Numb hands or feet
Shallow breathing
Shivering
Bright red, cold skin
Very low energy level

items: Confusion, memory loss , or slurred speech
Drop in body temperature below 95 F
Exhaustion or drowsiness
Loss of consciousness
Numb hands or feet
Shallow breathing
Shivering

sections.heading: 2. Restore Warmth Slowly
bullets: Get the person indoors.
Remove wet clothing and dry the person off, if needed.
Warm the person's trunk first, not hands and feet. Warming extremities first can cause shock.
Warm the person by wrapping them in blankets or putting dry clothing on the person.
Do not immerse the person in warm water. Rapid warming can cause heart arrhythmia .
If using hot water bottles or chemical hot packs, wrap them in cloth; don't apply them directly to the skin.

If using hot water bottles or chemical hot packs, wrap them in cloth; don't apply them directly to the skin.

sections.heading: 3. Begin CPR, if Necessary, While Warming Person
content: If the person is not breathing, start CPR immediately. Hypothermia causes respiratory rates to plunge, and a pulse might be difficult to detect.
bullets: For a child, start CPR for children .
For an adult, start adult CPR .
Continue CPR until the person begins breathing or emergency help arrives.

sections.heading: 4. Give Warm Fluids
bullets: Give the person a warm drink, if conscious. Avoid caffeine or alcohol.

items: Give the person a warm drink, if conscious. Avoid caffeine or alcohol.

sections.heading: 5. Keep Body Temperature Up
bullets: Once the body temperature begins to rise, keep the person dry and wrapped in a warm blanket. Wrap the person's head and neck, as well.

items: Once the body temperature begins to rise, keep the person dry and wrapped in a warm blanket. Wrap the person's head and neck, as well.

sections.heading: 6. Follow Up
bullets: At the hospital, health care providers will continue warming efforts, including providing intravenous fluids and warm, moist oxygen.

items: At the hospital, health care providers will continue warming efforts, including providing intravenous fluids and warm, moist oxygen.
